properties.areaDesc: Wabash, IL; Daviess, IN; Knox, IN; Gibson, IN; Pike, IN
properties.headline: Flood Warning issued February 10 at 11:25AM EST by NWS Indianapolis IN
properties.description:
...A Flood Warning continues for portions of the following waterways
in Indiana...

Driftwood River...East Fork White River...Eel River...Mississinewa
River...Wabash River...White River...Youngs Creek...


.Precipitation of up to about 2 inches fell Sunday into Monday,
heaviest within 50 miles north and south of Interstate 70.  This is
leading to mainly lowland flooding, but some county, state, and
federal roads may be impacted.  The Mississinewa River near
Ridgeville will come near or perhaps onto State Road 1 near State
Road 28.

Flooding is expected to occur at several locations on the Wabash
River from Montezuma southward and on the White River from Centerton
southward.  Flooding along the lower reaches will last past February
20.

Flooding on the Driftwood River is expected to last no more than a
couple days.

The Flood Warning continues for
The White River at Petersburg.
* from Tuesday morning until further notice.
* At 10:30 AM Monday the stage was 13.9 feet.
* Flood stage is 16.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...Rise above flood stage by Tuesday morning and continue
to rise to near 22.2 feet by Tuesday February 18.
* At 23.0 feet...Extensive flooding is progress affecting agricultural
and rural residential areas.  Several rural county roads
extensively flooded including Bottoms Rd...Brothers Rd and E.
Governor Rd in Knox County.  A few residents may move out in an
area locally known as Dodge City.  Several small oil fields are
inaccessible. During agricultural season much flood damage can
occur.  High water isolates some river cabin residents.
properties.instruction:
Precautionary/Preparedness Actions...

Motorists should never drive into flood water. Turn around and go
another way. Keep children away from flooded areas. Recreational and
agricultural interests should remain alert to changing river
conditions.

For detailed flood information go to weather.gov/ind on the web and
click on rivers and lakes.
